title: Ken Howard
text:
Kenneth Joseph Howard Jr. (March 28, 1944 – March 23, 2016) was an American actor, best known for his roles as <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> in "<a href="1776%20%28film%29">1776</a>" and as basketball coach and former <a href="Chicago%20Bulls">Chicago Bulls</a> player Ken Reeves in the television show "<a href="The%20White%20Shadow%20%28TV%20series%29">The White Shadow</a>" (1978–1981). Howard won the <a href="Tony%20Award%20for%20Best%20Featured%20Actor%20in%20a%20Play">Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Play</a> in 1970 for his performance in "<a href="Child%27s%20Play%20%28play%29">Child's Play</a>", and later won the <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20Supporting%20Actor%20in%20a%20Miniseries%20or%20a%20Movie">Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie</a> for his work in "<a href="Grey%20Gardens%20%282009%20film%29">Grey Gardens</a>" (2009).
Howard was elected president of the actors' <a href="Trade%20union">union</a>, <a href="Screen%20Actors%20Guild">Screen Actors Guild</a> (SAG), in September 2009 and reelected to a second term, in September 2011. He was the last president of the Screen Actors Guild and the first president of the newly formed union, <a href="SAG-AFTRA">SAG-AFTRA</a>, after the Screen Actors Guild and another union, the <a href="American%20Federation%20of%20Television%20and%20Radio%20Artists">American Federation of Television and Radio Artists</a> (AFTRA), voted to merge in 2012. He was reelected in 2015.
Early life.
Howard was born in <a href="El%20Centro%2C%20California">El Centro, California</a>, the son of Martha Carey (<a href="married%20and%20maiden%20names">née</a> McDonald) and Kenneth Joseph Howard, a stockbroker, being the elder of their two sons. His younger brother, the late Don Howard, was also an actor and director. His approximately 6-foot 6-inch (1.98 m) stature earned him the nickname "Stork" as a high school student. He grew up in <a href="Manhasset%2C%20New%20York">Manhasset, New York</a>, on <a href="Long%20Island">Long Island</a>.
The nickname "The White Shadow" was given to him by the Long Island press in 1961, as, at age 17, Howard was the only white starter on the <a href="Manhasset%20High%20School">Manhasset High School</a> varsity <a href="basketball">basketball</a> team.
A member of the <a href="National%20Honor%20Society">National Honor Society</a> in high school, Howard turned down several offers of basketball scholarships in favor of a more focused academic education. He graduated in 1966 from <a href="Amherst%20College">Amherst College</a>, where he served as captain of the basketball team. He was also a member of the <a href="a%20cappella">a cappella</a> singing group The Zumbyes. He attended <a href="Yale%20School%20of%20Drama">Yale School of Drama</a> but left to make his <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> debut before completing his master's degree -- which he completed in 1999.
Theater.
Howard began his career on Broadway in "<a href="Promises%2C%20Promises%20%28musical%29">Promises, Promises</a>" with <a href="Jerry%20Orbach">Jerry Orbach</a>. In 1970, he won a <a href="Tony%20Award">Tony Award</a> as Best Supporting or Featured Actor (Dramatic) for "<a href="Child%27s%20Play%20%28play%29">Child's Play</a>." Howard later starred on <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> as <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> in "<a href="1776%20%28musical%29">1776</a>" and reprised the role in the <a href="1776%20%28film%29">1972 film</a>. His other Broadway appearances included "<a href="Seesaw%20%28musical%29">Seesaw</a>" in 1973 and "<a href="The%20Norman%20Conquests">The Norman Conquests</a>". Howard portrayed several U.S. presidents in the 1975 Broadway musical "<a href="1600%20Pennsylvania%20Avenue%20%28musical%29">1600 Pennsylvania Avenue</a>" and appeared as <a href="Warren%20G.%20Harding">Warren G. Harding</a> in "Camping with Henry and Tom" in 1995. He appeared in legitimate theater in many cities, most recently as <a href="Tip%20O%27Neill">Tip O'Neill</a> in a one-man show "According to Tip", at the <a href="New%20Repertory%20Theatre">New Repertory Theatre</a> in Watertown, Massachusetts.
Television.
On television, Howard appeared as Ken Reeves, a <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> high school basketball coach, in "<a href="The%20White%20Shadow%20%28TV%20series%29">The White Shadow</a>", produced by <a href="Bruce%20Paltrow">Bruce Paltrow</a> in 1978. Howard had the starring role in the 1973 TV series "<a href="Adam%27s%20Rib%20%28TV%20series%29">Adam's Rib</a>" opposite his good friend, and Paltrow's wife, <a href="Blythe%20Danner">Blythe Danner</a> (who also played wife Martha to his Thomas Jefferson in the film version of "1776"). He starred in "<a href="The%20Manhunter">The Manhunter</a>", a crime drama that was part of CBS's lineup for the 1974–75 television season.
Howard starred in the TV movie "<a href="Father%20Damien">Father Damien</a>" in 1980 and won a <a href="Daytime%20Emmy%20Award">Daytime Emmy Award</a> in 1981 for his performance as the ideal father in the CBS afternoon special "The Body Human: Facts for Boys". Howard's additional credits included "<a href="Sidney%20Sheldon">Sidney Sheldon</a>'s <a href="Rage%20of%20Angels">Rage of Angels</a>, 1983", the 2000 <a href="miniseries">miniseries</a> "<a href="Perfect%20Murder%2C%20Perfect%20Town">Perfect Murder, Perfect Town</a>", and the feature film "", both co-starring <a href="Kris%20Kristofferson">Kris Kristofferson</a>. He played the title character in the 1984 American Playhouse production of <a href="Mark%20Twain">Mark Twain</a>'s "<a href="Pudd%27nhead%20Wilson">Pudd'nhead Wilson</a>", having earlier played Twain on "<a href="Bonanza">Bonanza</a>". Later, he appeared as <a href="Garrett%20Boydston">Garrett Boydston</a> in "<a href="Dynasty%20%281981%20TV%20series%29">Dynasty</a>" and its spin-off "<a href="The%20Colbys">The Colbys</a>". In the early 1990s, he appeared on "<a href="Murder%2C%20She%20Wrote">Murder, She Wrote</a>" and, from 2001–04, in "<a href="Crossing%20Jordan">Crossing Jordan</a>" as the title character's father. In 2007, he appeared in the <a href="Jimmy%20Smits">Jimmy Smits</a> series "<a href="Cane%20%28TV%20series%29">Cane</a>".
Howard guest-starred on numerous television dramas. He was guest villain in "<a href="Hart%20to%20Hart">Hart to Hart Returns</a>", a 1993 made-for-TV movie. He also appeared in season one of "<a href="The%20West%20Wing">The West Wing</a>" as President Bartlet's first choice for US Supreme Court Justice in the episode "<a href="The%20Short%20List">The Short List</a>". His other dramatic guest roles included "<a href="NYPD%20Blue">NYPD Blue</a>", "<a href="The%20Practice">The Practice</a>", "<a href="Boston%20Legal">Boston Legal</a>", "<a href="Cold%20Case">Cold Case</a>", "<a href="Dirty%20Sexy%20Money">Dirty Sexy Money</a>", "<a href="Eli%20Stone">Eli Stone</a>", "<a href="Brothers%20%26amp%3B%20Sisters%20%282006%20TV%20series%29">Brothers and Sisters</a>", "", "<a href="Curb%20Your%20Enthusiasm">Curb Your Enthusiasm</a>", "<a href="Fairly%20Legal">Fairly Legal</a>", "<a href="Crossing%20Jordan">Crossing Jordan</a>", "<a href="The%20Closer">The Closer</a>", "<a href="Blue%20Bloods%20%28TV%20series%29">Blue Bloods</a>", "<a href="The%20Golden%20Girls">The Golden Girls</a>", "<a href="The%20Office%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">The Office</a>", and "<a href="30%20Rock">30 Rock</a>".
Film.
Howard made his movie debut in 1970, in "<a href="Tell%20Me%20That%20You%20Love%20Me%2C%20Junie%20Moon">Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon</a>", opposite <a href="Liza%20Minnelli">Liza Minnelli</a>. Numerous movie roles followed, in both dramatic and comedic roles, including: "<a href="Such%20Good%20Friends">Such Good Friends</a>", "<a href="1776%20%28film%29">1776</a>", "<a href="The%20Strange%20Vengeance%20of%20Rosalie">The Strange Vengeance of Rosalie</a>", "Independence", "<a href="Second%20Thoughts%20%281983%20film%29">Second Thoughts</a>", "<a href="Oscar%20%281991%20film%29">Oscar</a>" with <a href="Sylvester%20Stallone">Sylvester Stallone</a> in 1991, "Ulterior Motives", "<a href="Clear%20and%20Present%20Danger%20%28film%29">Clear and Present Danger</a>" with <a href="Harrison%20Ford">Harrison Ford</a> in 1994, "<a href="The%20Net%20%281995%20film%29">The Net</a>" with <a href="Sandra%20Bullock">Sandra Bullock</a> in 1995, "<a href="Tactical%20Assault">Tactical Assault</a>", "", and "<a href="In%20Her%20Shoes%20%282005%20film%29">In Her Shoes</a>" in 2005.
In 2007, Howard appeared again with Stallone in "<a href="Rambo%20%282008%20film%29">Rambo</a>", and in <a href="George%20Clooney">George Clooney</a>'s "<a href="Michael%20Clayton%20%28film%29">Michael Clayton</a>". In 2010, he starred in "The Numbers Game" with <a href="Steven%20Bauer">Steven Bauer</a>. He next appeared as <a href="Harlan%20F.%20Stone">Harlan F. Stone</a> in <a href="Clint%20Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a>'s "<a href="J.%20Edgar">J. Edgar</a>".
He gave an acclaimed performance as <a href="Phelan%20Beale">Phelan Beale</a> in the 2009 <a href="HBO">HBO</a> film "<a href="Grey%20Gardens%20%282009%20film%29">Grey Gardens</a>", playing opposite <a href="Jessica%20Lange">Jessica Lange</a>, for which he received an <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a>. His last films were "<a href="Better%20Living%20Through%20Chemistry%20%28film%29">Better Living Through Chemistry</a>" (2013), "<a href="A.C.O.D.">A.C.O.D.</a>"(2013), "<a href="The%20Judge%20%282014%20film%29">The Judge</a>" (2014), "<a href="The%20Wedding%20Ringer">The Wedding Ringer</a>" (2015) and the <a href="Biographical%20film">biographical</a> <a href="comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> film "<a href="Joy%20%28film%29">Joy</a>" (2015).
Ken Howard was elected the National President of The Screen Actors Guild on September 24, 2009.
Author.
Howard was the author of the 2003 book "Act Natural: How to Speak to Any Audience", based on the drama courses he had taught at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a>. He was a popular reader for audiobooks.
Death.
Actors' union <a href="SAG-AFTRA">SAG-AFTRA</a> announced his death on Wednesday, March 23, 2016, five days before his 72nd birthday, but gave no cause. "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a>" noted that Howard "was diagnosed with stage four prostate cancer in 2007 and was recently hospitalized with a case of shingles." However, Howard died in Valencia, California, on March 23, 2016, of pneumonia complicated by <a href="shingles">shingles</a> and <a href="prostate%20cancer">prostate cancer</a>. He was the first and, so far, only <a href="Screen%20Actors%20Guild">Screen Actors Guild</a> or <a href="SAG-AFTRA">SAG-AFTRA</a> national president to die in the office.
<a href="George%20Clooney">George Clooney</a>, in whose 2007 legal thriller "<a href="Michael%20Clayton%20%28film%29">Michael Clayton</a>", Howard appeared, remembered having met him for the first time, in 1983 at <a href="20th%20Century%20Fox">20th Century Fox</a>, as a fan of "The White Shadow".
Howard was married three times. His first wife was actress <a href="Louise%20Sorel">Louise Sorel</a> (m. 1973–75). His second wife was writer and advice columnist <a href="Margo%20Howard">Margo Howard</a> (m. 1977–91). His final marriage was to stuntwoman Linda Fetters Howard (m. 1992–2016).
